prior_works.title: Asymptotically Efficient Adaptive Allocation Rules
prior_works.role: Foundational lower bounds and asymptotic sampling proportions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the asymptotic lower bounds and deterministic target allocation proportions that serve as the benchmark for assessing UCB-type algorithms, providing the reference point against which this paper contrasts UCB-V’s potential instability of arm-pulling rates.

prior_works.title: Optimal Adaptive Policies for Sequential Allocation Problems
prior_works.role: Asymptotically optimal index policies and allocation characterization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Characterized asymptotically optimal allocation rules via KL-based indices, informing the notion of target sampling proportions that the present work leverages when interpreting UCB-V’s asymptotics and refined regret.

prior_works.title: Finite-time Analysis of the Multiarmed Bandit Problem
prior_works.role: Canonical UCB algorithm and finite-time analysis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the UCB framework and its finite-time guarantees, forming the canonical baseline whose recent precise asymptotic analyses are extended here to the variance-aware UCB-V setting.

prior_works.title: Exploration–Exploitation Tradeoff Using Variance Estimates
prior_works.role: Introduced UCB-V and empirical-Bernstein style confidence radii
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Proposed the variance-aware UCB-V algorithm studied in this paper; its empirical-variance-based confidence design underpins the non-asymptotic high-probability pull-count bounds and refined regret derived here.

prior_works.title: Precise Asymptotics for UCB
prior_works.role: Pathwise characterization of arm-pulling rates for canonical UCB
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided precise, instance-dependent asymptotics for UCB’s arm-pulling counts; this paper extends that pathwise methodology to the variance-aware case, revealing that UCB-V can exhibit non-deterministic asymptotic pull fractions.

prior_works.title: Refined Asymptotics and High-Probability Bounds for UCB
prior_works.role: Refined pull-count asymptotics and high-probability control for UCB
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Further sharpened the precise asymptotic and high-probability understanding of canonical UCB; the present work adapts these techniques to derive non-asymptotic pull-count bounds and refined regret for UCB-V.

prior_works.title: Empirical Bernstein Bounds and Sample Variance Penalization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the empirical-Bernstein concentration machinery that justifies variance-aware confidence widths, enabling the high-probability analysis central to the paper’s refined regret guarantees for UCB-V.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—precise asymptotics for UCB-V’s arm-pulling rates, the discovery of potential instability (non-deterministic limiting fractions), and refined high-probability regret—rests on three intertwined lines of prior work. First, classical asymptotic theory by Lai and Robbins and its KL-index refinement by Burnetas and Katehakis established the benchmark of deterministic target sampling proportions and asymptotically optimal allocation, which frame what “stable” long-run behavior should look like. Second, the algorithmic lineage from Auer, Cesa-Bianchi, and Fischer’s UCB to Audibert, Munos, and Szepesvári’s UCB-V provides both the canonical baseline and the specific variance-aware index under study; the latter’s empirical-variance radii naturally call for empirical-Bernstein concentration, as formalized by Maurer and Pontil, to secure tight, time-uniform high-probability controls. Third, recent precise analyses of canonical UCB by Kalvit and Zeevi and by Khamaru and Zhang developed pathwise, instance-dependent characterizations of pull counts and refined non-asymptotic bounds. This paper extends that methodological toolkit to the variance-aware regime, showing that the additional stochasticity introduced by variance estimation can disrupt the deterministic sampling proportions seen in canonical UCB, leading to instability. Leveraging empirical-Bernstein-style control, the authors also derive high-probability bounds on pull counts that translate into refined, instance-dependent regret bounds for UCB-V—results that were previously unavailable even for this classic variance-aware algorithm.
